content:
{{knowledge objective
|Identifiant=OIC-364-11-A
|Item_parent=Fractures in children: epidemiological, diagnostic and therapeutic features
|Item_parent_short=Fractures in children: epidemiological, diagnostic and therapeutic features
|Rank=A
|Title=Knowing how to diagnose an ankle fracture
|Description=None
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=
|Order=11}}

<There are 2 main types of ankle fracture in children: type I or II epiphyseal dislocations, which tend to occur in young children and are usually treated orthopaedically; and type III or IV epiphyseal dislocations, which tend to occur in adolescents and are usually treated surgically.

question.question: What are the two main types of ankle fracture in children?
question.option_a: Type I or II epiphyseal dislocations
question.option_b: Type III or IV epiphyseal dislocations
question.option_c: Type V or VI epiphyseal dislocations
question.option_d: Type VII or VIII epiphyseal dislocations
